verses.latin: Idcirco erit vobis iniquitas haec, quasi ruptura cadens, et eminens in pariete, quae subito veniet in tempore inopinato.
verses.english: This iniquity will be for you like a breach, falling and bulging in a wall, which will suddenly come at an unexpected time.

verses.latin: Et confringetur quasi vas figuli, et contritione conteretur, et non invenietur in contritione ejus testa in qua portetur ignis de foco, aut hauriatur aqua de cisternis.
verses.english: It will break like a potter's vessel, and be shattered, so that there will not be found among its fragments a piece with which to carry fire from the hearth, or to draw water from the cisterns.

verses.latin: Quia haec dicit Dominus Deus, Sanctus Israël: In conversione et silentio erit fortitudo vestra, et in spe et in justitia erit robur vestrum. Et noluistis.
verses.english: For the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel, says this: “In repentance and silence is your strength, and in hope and in justice will be your power.” But you would not.

verses.latin: Et dixistis: Nequaquam, sed fugiemus in equis: ideo fugietis. Et super velocibus ascendemus: ideo veloces erunt qui persequentur vos.
verses.english: And you said, “No, we will flee on horses.” Therefore you shall flee. “We will ride on swift horses.” Therefore those who pursue you will be swift.

verses.latin: Mille homines fugient a facie unius, et a facie quinque fugietis donec residui fueritis quasi malus in vertice montis, et quasi signum super collis.
verses.english: A thousand men will flee at the sight of one, and at the sight of five you will flee, until you are left like a pole on the top of a mountain, and like a banner on a hill.

verses.latin: Et propterea exspectat Dominus, ut misereatur vestri: et ideo exaltabitur, parcens vobis: quia Deus judicii Dominus, beati omnes qui exspectant eum.
verses.english: And therefore the Lord waits to have mercy on you: and therefore He will be exalted, sparing you: for the Lord is a God of judgment, and blessed are all who wait for Him.

verses.latin: Populus enim in Sion habitabit in Jerusalem: plorans plorabis, ad vocem clamoris tui statim ut audierit te, respondebit tibi.
verses.english: For a people will dwell in Zion at Jerusalem: You will weep, and at the sound of your cry, as soon as He hears you, He will answer you.

verses.latin: Et dabit vobis Dominus panem angustiae et aquam tribulationis: et non auferet a te doctorem tuum, et oculi tui videbunt doctorem tuum.
verses.english: And the Lord will give you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction: your teacher will not be removed from you, and your eyes will see your teacher.

verses.latin: Et aures tuae audient verbum post tergum monentis: Haec est via, ambulate in ea: et non declinetis neque ad dextram, neque ad sinistram.
verses.english: And your ears will hear a word behind you, saying, “This is the way, walk in it,” neither turning to the right nor the left.

verses.latin: Et contaminabis laminas sculptilium argenti tui, et vestimentum conflatilis auri tui, et disperges ea sicut immundum: egredere, dices ei.
verses.english: And you will defile the plates of your carved silver, and the garment of your molten gold, and you will scatter them as an unclean thing: “Get out,” you will say to it.

verses.latin: Et dabitur pluvia semini tuo, ubicumque seminaveris in terra: et panis frugum terrae erit uberrimus et pinguis: in die illa pascet pecus tuum in latitudine pascuorum.
verses.english: And rain will be given to your seed, wherever you sow it in the land: and the bread from the produce of the earth will be most abundant and rich: in that day your livestock will graze in wide pastures.

verses.latin: Et tauri et asini qui arabant terram, comedent confectum sapore, quod ventilatum est in area.
verses.english: And the bulls and the asses that plow the land will eat fodder seasoned with flavor, which has been winnowed in the threshing floor.

verses.latin: Et erunt super omnem montem excelsum, et super omnem collem elevatum, rivi currentium aquarum, in die interfectionis multorum, cum ceciderint turres.
verses.english: And on every high mountain, and on every elevated hill, there will be streams of flowing water, on the day when many are slain, when the towers fall.

verses.latin: Et erit lux lunae sicut lux solis, et lux solis erit septupla, sicut lux septem dierum, in die qua alligaverit Dominus vulnus populi sui, et dolorem plagae ejus sanaverit.
verses.english: And the light of the moon will be like the light of the sun, and the light of the sun will be sevenfold, like the light of seven days, on the day when the Lord binds up the wound of His people and heals the pain of their wound.

verses.latin: Ecce nomen Domini venit de longinquo, ardens furor ejus, et gravis ad portandum: labia ejus repleta sunt indignatione, et lingua ejus quasi ignis vorans.
verses.english: Behold, the name of the Lord comes from afar, His burning anger, and heavy to bear: His lips are filled with indignation, and His tongue is like a consuming fire.

verses.latin: Spiritus ejus quasi torrens inundans usque ad collum: ad perdendas gentes in vanitate, et in freno erroris quod est in maxillis populorum.
verses.english: His Spirit is like an overflowing torrent up to the neck: to destroy the nations in vanity, and with the bridle of error that is in the jaws of the peoples.

verses.latin: Canticum erit vobis sicut nox sanctificatae solemnitatis, et laetitia cordis, sicut qui pergit ad audiendum tibi, in monte Domini, ad fortem Israël.
verses.english: Your song will be like the night of a consecrated festival, and the joy of the heart, like one who goes to hear, on the mountain of the Lord, to the strong one of Israel.

verses.latin: Et glorificabit Dominus vocem gloriae suae, et fortitudinem brachii sui audiet, in indignatione furoris, et flamma ignis voracis: irruens impetu.
verses.english: And the Lord will make His glorious voice heard, and will make them hear the strength of His arm, with the indignation of His fury, and the flame of a devouring fire, with a tempestuous attack.

verses.latin: A voce enim Domini conturbabitur Assur, virga percutietur.
verses.english: For at the voice of the Lord, Assyria will be troubled, and it will be struck with the rod.

verses.latin: Et erit transitus virgae fundatus, quam requiescere faciet Dominus super eum, in tympanis et citharis, et in bellis praecipuis pugnabit contra eos.
verses.english: And there will be a firm foundation for the rod that the Lord will make to rest upon him, with timbrels and harps, and He will fight against them in battles.

verses.latin: Tophet enim parata est ab heri, et ipsa quoque parata est regi: profundam et latam: ignis et ligna multa: flatus Domini sicut torrens sulphuris succendens eam.
verses.english: For Tophet is prepared of old, and it also is prepared for the king: deep and wide: with fire and much wood: the breath of the Lord will burn it like a torrent of sulfur.

verses.latin: Vae qui descendunt in Aegyptum in auxilium, sperantes in equis, et confidunt in curribus, eo quod multi sunt, et in equitibus, quia fortes: et non speraverunt in Sancto Israël, et Deum non quaesierunt.
verses.english: Woe to those who turn to Egypt for help, trusting in horses and chariots, because they are many, and in horsemen, because they are strong; but they have not put their trust in the Holy One of Israel, nor sought the Lord.

verses.latin: Ipse autem sapiens adduxit malum, et verba sua non abstulit: et consurget contra domum nequam, et contra auxilium operantium iniquitatem.
verses.english: But He Who is wise brought evil, and did not withdraw His word; He will arise against the house of the wicked, and against those who help do evil.

verses.latin: Aegyptus homo, et non Deus: et equi eorum caro, et non spiritus. Et cum extenderit manum suam, corruent auxiliarius, et cadet quem juvat, et simul omnes consumentur.
verses.english: Egypt is a man, not God; their horses are flesh, not spirit. When He stretches out His hand, the helper will fall, and he whom he helps will fall, and they will all perish together.

verses.latin: Quia haec dicit mihi Dominus: Quomodo rugiet leo, et catulus leonis super praedam suam, cum vocatus fuerit contra eum multitudo pastorum, a voce eorum non pavebit, neque conturbabitur a multitudine eorum: sic descendet Dominus exercituum ut pugnet super montem Sion, et super collem ejus.
verses.english: For thus says the Lord to me: "As the lion roars and the young lion over his prey, when a multitude of shepherds are called against him, he is not afraid at their voice or disturbed at their clamor, so the Lord of hosts will come down to fight on Mount Zion and on its hill."

verses.latin: Sicut aves volantes, sic proteget Dominus exercituum Jerusalem, protegens et liberans, transiens et salvans.
verses.english: Like birds hovering, so the Lord of hosts will protect Jerusalem; protecting and delivering, passing over and saving.

verses.latin: Convertimini ad eum a quo filii Israël recesserunt in profundum.
verses.english: Return to Him from whom the children of Israel have deeply departed.

verses.latin: In die enim illa abjiciet vir idola argenti sui, et idola auri sui, quae fecerunt vobis manus vestrae.
verses.english: For in that day every man shall cast away his idols of silver, and his idols of gold, which your hands have made for you.

verses.latin: Et corruet Assyrius in gladio non viri, et gladius non viri comedet eum: et fugiet a facie gladii, et transibunt electi ejus in tributum.
verses.english: Then the Assyrian shall fall by a sword, not of man; and a sword, not of man, shall devour him; and he shall flee from the face of the sword, and his chosen men shall pay tribute.

verses.latin: Et fortitudo ejus terrore transibit, et conturbabuntur principes ejus a vexillo, dicit Dominus: cujus ignis est in Sion, et caminus ejus in Jerusalem.
verses.english: And his strength shall pass away with fear, and his princes shall be afraid of the standard, says the Lord, whose fire is in Zion, and His furnace in Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Ecce in justitia regnabit rex, et principes in judicio praeerunt.
verses.english: Look! A king will rule with perfect justice, and his leaders will govern with righteous judgment.

verses.latin: Et erit vir sicut latibulum a vento, et tegens a fervore: sicut impetus aquarum in siti, et umbra petræ magnæ in terra deserta.
verses.english: And this man, the king, will be like a refuge from the wind, a cover from the scorching heat. He will be like rushing streams of water in a parched land, and the shade of a massive rock in a desolate desert.

verses.latin: Et non caligabunt oculi videntium, et aures audientium diligentius intendent.
verses.english: The eyes of those who truly see will no longer be dim, and the ears of those who truly hear will listen with greater attention.

verses.latin: Et cor stultorum intelleget scientiam, et lingua balbutientium velociter loquetur et plane.
verses.english: The minds of the foolish will then understand knowledge, and the tongues of those who stammer will speak quickly and clearly.

verses.latin: Non vocabitur ultra is qui insipiens est, princeps: neque fraudulentus appellabitur major.
verses.english: The foolish person will no longer be called a leader, nor will the deceitful be called a great man.

verses.latin: Quoniam stultus stulta loquetur, et cor ejus faciet iniquitatem, ut perficiat simulationem, et loquatur ad Dominum fallaciam, et vacuam faciat animam esurientis, et sitientis potum auferat.
verses.english: For the foolish person speaks foolish things, and his heart plots evil. He practices hypocrisy and speaks lies against the Lord. He leaves the hungry soul empty and deprives the thirsty of drink.

verses.latin: Fraudulenti quoque vasa pessima sunt: ipse enim cogitationes concinnat ut perdat mites sermone mendacii, cum loqueretur pauper et justum.
verses.english: The deceitful also use wicked schemes. He devises evil plans to destroy the humble with lying words, even when the poor man speaks what is right.

verses.latin: Princeps vero cogitat ea quæ sunt principis, et ipse stabit ad regimen principum.
verses.english: But the noble man plans noble things, and he will stand firm in noble leadership.

verses.latin: Mulieres opulentæ, surgite et audite vocem meam: filiæ confidentes, percipite auribus eloquium meum.
verses.english: Rise up, you complacent women, and listen to my voice! You overconfident daughters, pay close attention to my words!

verses.latin: Post dies et annum et vos conturbabimini confidentes: consugetur enim vindemia, collectio ultra non veniet.
verses.english: In just a little more than a year, you confident women will be troubled, for the grape harvest will fail completely; no produce will be gathered.

verses.latin: Exspavescite confidentes, conturbamini securæ: exspoliate vos, et denudate, accingite lumbos vestros cilicio.
verses.english: Tremble, you confident women! Be troubled, you carefree ones! Strip off your fine clothing and expose your bare skin. Gird sackcloth around your waists in mourning.

verses.latin: Super ubera plangite, super regione desiderii, super vite fertili.
verses.english: Beat your breasts in lamentation for the lovely fields, for the fruitful vine, and for all that was desirable.

verses.latin: Super terram populi mei spinas et tribulos ascendere, certe super omnes domos gaudii civitatis exsultantis.
verses.english: For upon the land of my people, thorns and thistles will grow, covering all the houses of joy in the once jubilant city.

verses.latin: Domus enim dimissa est, multitudo civitatis relicta est, caligo et tenebræ factæ sunt in speluncis usque ad ævum: gaudium onagrorum, pascua gregum.
verses.english: Indeed, the palace is abandoned, the bustling city is deserted. Gloom and darkness have settled in the desolate caves and ruins for a long time. It will become a place of delight for wild donkeys and a pasture for flocks.

verses.latin: Donec effundatur super nos spiritus de excelso: et erit desertum in carmel, et carmel in saltum reputabitur.
verses.english: This will continue until the Spirit from on high is poured out upon us. Then the wilderness will become a fruitful field, and the fruitful field will be considered a forest.

verses.latin: Et habitabit in deserto judicium, et justitia in carmelo sedebit.
verses.english: And justice will dwell in the wilderness, and righteousness will reside in the fruitful field.

verses.latin: Et erit opus justitiæ pax, et cultus justitiæ silentium et securitas usque ad sempiternum.
verses.english: And the effect of righteousness will be peace, and the result of righteousness will be quiet confidence and lasting security forever.

verses.latin: Et sedebit populus meus in pulchritudine pacis, et in tabernaculis fiduciæ, et in requie opulenta.
verses.english: Then my people will dwell in peaceful dwellings, in secure habitations, and in tranquil places of abundant rest.

verses.latin: Grando autem in descensu silvæ, et humilitate conteretur civitas.
verses.english: But hail will bring down the forest, and the city that caused humiliation will be utterly brought low.

verses.latin: Beati vos qui seminatis super omnes aquas, immittentes pedem bovis et asini.
verses.english: Blessed are you who sow seeds by all waters, letting the ox and the donkey freely tread the ground.

verses.latin: Vae qui praedaris, et ipse non praedaris: et cum consummaveris depopulationem, depopulaberis. An non, cum desieris contemnere, contemneris?
verses.english: Woe to you who plunders others, yet you yourself are not plundered by anyone in return. But when you finish your devastation, you yourself will be devastated in turn! Will you not, when you cease to despise others, then be despised yourself?

verses.latin: Domine miserere nostri, te enim sustinuimus: esto brachium nostrum in mane, et salus nostra in tempore tribulationis.
verses.english: O Lord, have mercy on us; for we have waited and hoped in You. Be our strength and the might of our arm every morning, and be our salvation in our time of tribulation and great distress.

verses.latin: A voce angeli fugerunt populi: et ab elevatione tua dispersae sunt gentes.
verses.english: At the sound of God’s powerful messenger, the nations that oppress His people will flee in terror. From Your rising up in power, the Gentile nations will be scattered.

verses.latin: Et congregabuntur spolia vestra sicut colligitur bruchus, sicut si compleri solent locustae, ita complenda est.
verses.english: And your plunder, O oppressor, will be gathered up by your victims just like a swarm of locusts gathers over a field. Just as locusts gather, so will your spoils be gathered from you.

verses.latin: Magnus Dominus quoniam excelsus habitat: implevit Sion judicio et justitia.
verses.english: Great is the Lord, because He dwells on high, in the heavens above the universe. He has filled Sion (the City of God) with justice and righteousness.

verses.latin: Et erit fides in temporibus tuis: divitiae salutis, sapientia et scientia: terror Domini, ipse est thesaurus ejus.
verses.english: And there will be faithfulness and stability in your times. The riches of your salvation will be wisdom and true knowledge. The reverence and awe of the Lord Himself is the treasure that God gives to His people.

verses.latin: Ecce videntes in foris, plorabunt: angeli pacis amare flebunt.
verses.english: Behold, the watchmen who look out from the public squares will weep in sorrow. The messengers of peace, who went to negotiate with the oppressors, will weep bitterly.

verses.latin: Dissipatae sunt viae, cessavit transitio pedis: irritum factum est pactum, projecit civitates, non reputavit homines.
verses.english: The roads are desolate and deserted; the passage of travelers has ceased. The treaties and covenants made with the oppressor have been made void. He has rejected and destroyed cities, and he has shown no regard for human life.

verses.latin: Luxit et elanguit terra: Libanus confusus est et emarcuit: et factus est Saron sicut desertum: et commota est Basan, et Carmelus.
verses.english: The land itself mourns and wastes away in sorrow. Lebanon is put to shame and its forests have withered. The fertile Plain of Sharon has become like a desert, and the rich regions of Bashan and Carmel are devastated.

verses.latin: Nunc consurgam, dicit Dominus: nunc exaltabor, nunc levabor.
verses.english: Now I will arise, says the Lord. Now I will be exalted in power. Now I will be lifted up and glorified.

verses.latin: Concipietis ardorem, parietis stipulam: spiritus vester quasi ignis comedet vos.
verses.english: You, the oppressors, will conceive only trouble and bring forth only stubble and chaff. Your own spirit, your own rage and wickedness, will consume you like a devouring fire.

verses.latin: Et erunt populi quasi cinis succensus: spinae conculcatae igne comburentur.
verses.english: And the peoples who oppose Me will be like burned lime, reduced to ashes. Like thorns that have been trampled, they will be completely burned up by fire.

verses.latin: Audite qui prope estis quae fecerim: et cognoscite de longe fortitudinem meam.
verses.english: Hear, you who are near to Me, what I have done. And you who are far off, acknowledge My strength and My power.

verses.latin: Conterriti sunt in Sion peccatores, possedit tremor hypocritas. Quis poterit de vobis habitare cum igne devorante? quis poterit habitare vobiscum in ardoribus sempiternis?
verses.english: The sinners in Sion are terrified. Trembling has seized the hypocrites and the godless. Who among you, then, will be able to dwell with a devouring fire, which is the righteous judgment of God? Who among you will be able to dwell with everlasting burnings?

verses.latin: Qui ambulat in justitiis, et loquitur veritatem, qui projicit avaritiam ex manu sua, et excutit manum suam ab omni munere, qui obturat aures suas ne audiat sanguinem, et claudit oculos suos ne videat malum.
verses.english: It is he who walks in true righteousness and speaks the truth, rejecting dishonest gain from his hand and shaking his hand to refuse every bribe. He stops his ears from listening to talk of bloodshed and closes his eyes from looking upon evil.

verses.latin: Iste in excelsis habitabit: munimenta saxorum erit sublimitas ejus: panis ei datus est, aquae ejus fideles sunt.
verses.english: Such a person will dwell securely on high, in elevated places. The fortresses of rocks will be his refuge and his stronghold. He is given his daily bread, and his water supply is sure and constant.

verses.latin: Regem in decore suo videbunt oculi ejus, videbunt terram de longe.
verses.english: His eyes will see the King, God Himself, in His splendor and majesty. They will also see the promised land stretching out far away into the distance.

verses.latin: Cor tuum meditabitur terrorem: Ubi litteratus? ubi ponderans verba legis? ubi magnus?
verses.english: Your heart will recall the terror and distress of the past. Then you will ask: 'Where is the scribe who recorded the tribute? Where is he who weighed the tax money? Where is the mighty oppressor who counted the towers for siege?'

verses.latin: Populum impudentem non videbis, populum profundi sermonis, ita ut intelligere non possis sermonem: et impudentis linguae, ita ut non possis intelligere.
verses.english: You will no longer see the insolent and arrogant people who invaded your land. You will not see the people whose language was so deep and foreign that you could not understand their speech; nor will you hear their arrogant tongue, which you could not comprehend.

verses.latin: Intuere Sion civitatem solemnitatis nostrae: oculi tui videbunt Jerusalem, opulentam habitaculum, tentorium quod non auferetur, nec transferentur clavi ejus in sempiternum, et universa funiculi ejus non rumpentur.
verses.english: Look upon Sion, the city of our solemn feasts and holy gatherings! Your eyes will see Jerusalem, a peaceful and prosperous dwelling place. It will be like a tent that will never be taken down; its tent pegs will never be removed for all time, and none of its ropes will ever break.

verses.latin: Quia ibi magnificus est Dominus noster: locus fluviorum, rivorum latissimorum et patentium: non transibit per eum navis remigis, neque navis magna transibit per eum.
verses.english: For there, in Jerusalem, our Lord will be glorious and powerful. He will be to us like mighty rivers, broad and wide-flowing streams, providing impenetrable defense. No warship rowed by enemies will pass through it, nor will any great ship of war sail upon it.

verses.latin: Dominus enim judex noster, Dominus legifer noster, Dominus rex noster: ipse salvabit nos.
verses.english: For the Lord is our Judge. The Lord is our Lawgiver. The Lord is our King. He Himself will save us.

verses.latin: Soluta sunt funiculi tui, et non praevalebunt: sic infirmabitur malus eorum ut naves tuas nullo modo teneant. Diripietur tunc praeda multorum: claudi diripient rapinam.
verses.english: The ropes of your enemy's 'ship' (their military strength and siege equipment) are slackened and loose; they will not hold firm. Their mast is so weakened that it cannot stand upright, and their sails cannot hold any wind to move their ships (your captured cities). Then, the plunder of many nations will be divided. Even the lame and weak will seize the spoil and share in the plunder.

verses.latin: Nec dicet vicinus: Laboravi. Populus qui habitat in ea, auferetur ab eo iniquitas.
verses.english: And no resident in the land will say: 'I am sick' or 'I am weak.' The people who dwell in it will have their iniquity, their sins, taken away from them and forgiven.

verses.latin: Accedite gentes, et audite; et populi attendite: audiat terra, et plenitudo ejus; orbis, et omnes qui germinant ex eo.
verses.english:
Approach, all you nations, and listen carefully.
All you peoples, pay attention.
Let the entire earth hear this, with all its inhabitants.
Let the whole world and everyone living on it understand.

verses.latin: Quia indignatio Domini super omnes gentes, et furor super universam militiam eorum: interficiet eos, et dabit eos in cædem.
verses.english:
Because the Lord's strong anger is against all the nations,
and His fury is upon all their armies.
He will destroy them completely,
and hand them over to be slaughtered.

verses.latin: Et interfecti eorum projicientur, et de cadaveribus eorum ascendet fœtor: tabescent montes sanguine eorum.
verses.english:
Their dead bodies will be thrown out unburied.
A terrible stench will rise from their corpses.
The mountains will be soaked and appear to melt away from the vast amount of their blood.

verses.latin: Et tabescet omnis militia cælorum, et complicabitur sicut liber cæli: et omnes exercitus eorum decident, sicut decidit folium de vinea, et de ficu.
verses.english:
Then all the stars in the universe will dissolve,
and the sky will be rolled up like a scroll.
All the celestial bodies, like an army, will fall
just as leaves fall from a vine or from a fig tree.

verses.latin: Quoniam inebriatus est in cælo gladius meus: ecce super Idumæam descendit, et super populum interfectionis meæ.
verses.english:
For My sword has been readied and made to strike in the spiritual realm of God.
Now, behold, it descends upon Edom,
and upon the people whom I have destined for utter destruction.

verses.latin: Gladius Domini repletus est sanguine, incrassatus est adipe, de sanguine agnorum et hircorum, de adipe arietum et taurorum: victima enim Domini in Bosra, et cædes magna in terra Idumæa.
Et descendent unicornes cum eis, et tauri in bubalis: et inebriabitur terra eorum sanguine, et humus eorum pinguedine sanctorum.
verses.english:
And the wild oxen, with their great strength, will be brought down with them,
and the mighty bulls along with the wild cattle.
Their land will be drenched and made to drink their blood,
and their soil will be enriched with the fat of their powerful people, set apart for destruction.

verses.latin: Quia dies ultionis Domini, annus retributionum ad judicandum Sion.
verses.english:
For this is the day of the Lord's vengeance,
the year of recompense, to bring justice for Zion.

verses.latin: Et convertentur torrentes ejus in picem, et humus ejus in sulphur: et erit terra ejus in picem ardentem.
verses.english:
Then Edom's streams will be turned into burning tar,
and its soil into brimstone.
Its entire land will become a blazing inferno of tar.

verses.latin: Nocte et die non extinguetur, semper ascendet fumus ejus: a generatione in generationem erit deserta, in sæculum sæculorum nemo pertransibit per eam.
verses.english:
It will not be extinguished day or night;
its smoke will rise up forever.
From one generation to the next, it will remain a desolate wasteland.
No one will ever pass through it again, for all eternity.

verses.latin: Et possidebit illam onocrotalus, et ericius: et ibis et corvus habitabunt in ea: et extendet super eam mensuram vacuitatis, et perpendiculum annihilationis.
verses.english:
The pelican and the hedgehog will possess it.
The owl and the raven will make their home there.
God will stretch over it the measuring line of emptiness,
and the plummet of annihilation, ensuring its complete destruction.

verses.latin: Nobiles ejus non erunt ibi, sed potius reges ejus et principes.
verses.english:
Her nobles will no longer be found there.
Indeed, there will be no one left to be her kings or princes either.

verses.latin: Et orientur in domibus ejus spinæ, et urticæ, et balani in munitionibus ejus: et erit cubile draconum, et pascua struthionum.
verses.english:
Thorns will grow in her palaces,
and nettles and brambles in her fortresses.
It will become a lair for jackals,
and a dwelling place for ostriches.

verses.latin: Et occurrent dæmonia onocentauris, et pilosus clamabit alter ad alterum: ibi cubavit lamia, et invenit sibi requiem.
verses.english:
Wild demons will meet with howling hyenas;
and the hairy satyrs will cry out to one another.
There, the night hag will come to rest,
and find her own place of quiet.

verses.latin: Ibi nidificavit cinifis, et peperit, et circumfodit, et fovit in umbra sua: illuc congregati sunt milvi, alter ad alterum.
verses.english:
There the screech owl will make her nest, lay her eggs, hatch them,
and gather her young under her wings.
Indeed, kites will also gather there, one calling to another.

verses.latin: Requirite diligenter de libro Domini, et legite: unum ex his non cecidit, et alter ad alterum non quæsivit: quia os Domini mandavit, et spiritus ejus ipse congregavit ea.
verses.english:
Search diligently in the book of the Lord and read this carefully.
Not one of these prophecies will fail,
nor will any of these creatures be missing their mate or their place.
For the mouth of the Lord has commanded it,
and His very Spirit has gathered them together.

verses.latin: Et ipse misit eis sortem, et manus ejus divisit eis in mensura: usque in æternum possidebunt illam, in generatione et generatione habitabunt in ea.
verses.english:
God Himself has cast lots to determine their portion,
and His hand has measured out their inheritance for them.
They will possess that land forever,
and from generation to generation, they will dwell in it.

verses.latin: Laetabitur deserta et invia, et exsultabit solitudo, et florebit quasi lilium.
verses.english: The deserted and pathless regions will rejoice. The solitary wilderness will be glad and will blossom like a lily, bursting forth in life.

verses.latin: Germinans germinabit, et exsultabit laetabunda et laudans: gloria Libani data est ei: decor Carmeli et Saron. Ipsi videbunt gloriam Domini, et decorem Dei nostri.
verses.english: It will burst forth with abundant growth and will rejoice with overflowing gladness and praise. The splendor of Lebanon will be given to it, and the beauty of Carmel and Sharon. All the people there will see the glory of the Lord and the magnificent beauty of our God.

verses.latin: Confortate manus dissolutas, et genua debilia roborate.
verses.english: Strengthen the feeble hands and make firm the weak knees.

verses.latin: Dicite pusillanimis: Confortamini, et nolite timere: ecce Deus vester ultionem adducet retributionis; Deus ipse veniet, et salvabit vos.
verses.english: Say to those who are fainthearted: "Be strong, and do not be afraid! Behold, your God will come with divine justice and a just retribution. God Himself will come to rescue and save you."

verses.latin: Tunc aperientur oculi caecorum, et aures surdorum patebunt.
verses.english: Then the eyes of those who are blind will be opened, and the ears of those who are deaf will be unstopped.

verses.latin: Tunc saliet claudus sicut cervus, et aperta erit lingua mutorum: quia scissae sunt in deserto aquae, et torrentes in solitudine.
verses.english: Then the lame will leap like a stag, and the tongue of those who cannot speak will be made clear. For waters will burst forth in the deserted regions, and streams of water will flow in the solitary wilderness.

verses.latin: Et quae erat arida, erit in stagnum, et sitiens in fontes aquarum: in cubilibus draconum, in quibus habitabant prius, orietur viror calami et junci.
verses.english: The dry ground will be transformed into ponds, and the thirsty land into flowing springs of water. In the dens where wild beasts once lived, there will arise verdant reeds and rushes, turning their desolate homes into a lush swamp.

verses.latin: Et erit ibi semita et via, et via sancta vocabitur: non transibit per eam immundus, et haec erit vobis directa via, ita ut stulti non errent per eam.
verses.english: And there will be a designated path and a true road there, and it will be called "the Holy Way." No unclean person will pass through it. This will be a straightforward path for you, so clear that even foolish people will not go astray on it.

verses.latin: Non erit ibi leo, et mala bestia non ascendet per eam, nec invenietur ibi: et ambulabunt qui liberati sunt.
verses.english: No lion will be there, and no savage beast will go up on it or be found there. Only those who have been set free will walk upon it.

verses.latin: Et redempti Domini revertentur, et venient in Sion cum laude, et laetitia sempiterna super capita eorum: gaudium et laetitiam tenebunt, et fugiet dolor et gemitus.
verses.english: And the Lord's redeemed people will return. They will come to Zion—the holy city of Jerusalem, their spiritual home—with praise, and with everlasting joy upon their heads. They will possess joy and gladness, and all sorrow and sighing will flee far away.

verses.latin: Et factum est in quarto decimo anno regis Hezechiae, ascendit Sennacherib rex Assyriorum super omnes civitates Judae munitas, et cepit eas.
verses.english: It happened in the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah's reign: Sennacherib, the king of the Assyrians, attacked all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

verses.latin: Et misit rex Assyriorum Rabsacen de Lachis in Jerusalem ad regem Hezechiam in multitudine magna: et stetit in aquæductu Piscinæ superioris in via Agri fullonis.
verses.english: From Lachish, the Assyrian king sent Rabshakeh with a large army to Jerusalem, to confront King Hezekiah. Rabshakeh took his position by the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, on the road that leads to the Fuller's Field.

verses.latin: Et egressus est ad eum Eliacim filius Helciae praepositus domus, et Sobna scriba, et Joah filius Asaph cancellarius.
verses.english: Then Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah and the steward of the king's household, along with Shebna the royal scribe, and Joah, the son of Asaph and the recorder, went out to meet him.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad eos Rabsaces: Dicite Hezechiae: Haec dicit rex magnus, rex Assyriorum: Quae est ista fiducia, qua confidis?
verses.english: Rabshakeh spoke to them, saying: 'Tell Hezekiah: Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: What is this confidence you rely on? What gives you this certainty?'

verses.latin: Forsitan inisti consilium, et fortitudo ad proelia? et nunc super quem confidis, quia rebellasti contra me?
verses.english: 'Do you think you have a strategy and strength sufficient for battle? So, tell me, on whom are you relying now, since you have openly rebelled against me?'

verses.latin: Ecce confidis super baculum arundineum confractum istum, super Ægyptum, super quem si innitatur homo, transverberabit manum ejus, et forabit eam: sic est Pharao rex Ægypti omnibus confindentibus in se.
verses.english: 'Look, you are relying on Egypt, that broken reed staff. If a man leans on it, it will pierce his hand and wound it deeply. That is exactly what Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, is to all who trust in him.'

verses.latin: Quod si dixeritis mihi: In Domino Deo nostro confidimus: numquid non est iste, cujus abstulit Hezechias excelsa, et altaria, et praecepit Juda, et Jerusalem: Ante altare hoc adorabitis?
verses.english: 'But if you tell me, "We trust in the Lord our God," is He not the very One whose high places and altars Hezekiah removed, when he commanded Judah and Jerusalem: "You shall worship before this altar only"?'

verses.latin: Et nunc transite ad Dominum meum regem Assyriorum, et dabo vobis duo millia equorum, si potueris ex te praebere ascensores eorum.
verses.english: 'Now, make a pledge to my lord, the king of Assyria, and I will give you two thousand horses—if you can even find enough riders among yourselves for them.'

verses.latin: Et quomodo potes resistere uni principi de servis Domini mei minimis? et confidis super Ægyptum in quadrigis et in equitibus.
verses.english: 'How then can you resist even one of the least of my master's officials? Yet you rely on Egypt for chariots and for horsemen.'

verses.latin: Et nunc numquid sine Domino ascendi ad terram istam, ut disperderem eam? Dominus dixit ad me: Ascende super terram istam, et disperde eam.
verses.english: 'Furthermore, have I come up against this land to destroy it without the Lord's approval? The Lord Himself said to me: "Go up against this land and destroy it."'

verses.latin: Et dixit Eliacim, et Sobna, et Joah ad Rabsacen: Loquere ad servos tuos syra lingua: siquidem intelligimus eam: et ne loquaris ad nos judaice, in auribus populi qui est super murum.
verses.english: Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to Rabshakeh: 'Please, speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak to us in the language of Judah, where all the people listening on the wall can hear you.'

verses.latin: Et dixit Rabsaces: Numquid ad Dominum tuum et ad te misit me Dominus meus, ut loquerer omnes sermones istos? et non potius ad viros, qui sedent super murum, ut comedant stercora sua, et bibant urinam suam vobiscum?
verses.english: But Rabshakeh replied: 'Did my master send me to speak all these words only to your master and to you? No, he sent me precisely to the men sitting on the wall, so that they will understand that soon they will be forced to eat their own excrement and drink their own urine with you, from the extreme hunger and thirst of the siege.'

verses.latin: Et stetit Rabsaces, et exclamavit voce magna judaice, et dixit: Audite verba regis magni, regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: So Rabshakeh stood up and shouted with a loud voice in the language of Judah, saying: 'Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!'

verses.latin: Haec dicit rex: Non vos seducat Hezechias, neque enim poterit eruere vos.
verses.english: 'Thus says the king: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will surely not be able to rescue you.'

verses.latin: Et non vobis persuadere faciat Hezechias super Domino, dicens: Eruens eruet nos Dominus: non dabitur civitas ista in manu regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: 'Do not let Hezekiah make you trust in the Lord, by saying: "The Lord will surely deliver us! This city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria."'

verses.latin: Nolite audire Hezechiam: haec enim dicit rex Assyriorum: Facite mecum aliquid benedictionis, et egredimini ad me: et unumquisque comedet vineam suam, et unumquisque ficum suam, et bibet unusquisque aquam de cisterna sua.
verses.english: 'Do not listen to Hezekiah! For thus says the king of Assyria: Make a treaty with me and come out to me. Then each of you may eat from his own vine and from his own fig tree, and drink water from his own cistern.'

verses.latin: Donec veniam, et auferam vos ad terram sicut terram vestram, terram frumenti et vini, terram panis et vinearum.
verses.english: 'Until I come and take you away to a land just like your own land—a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.'

verses.latin: Nequaquam vos seducat Hezechias, dicens: Dominus liberabit nos. Numquid liberaverunt dii gentium, unusquisque terram suam de manu regis Assyriorum?
verses.english: 'Do not let Hezekiah mislead you by saying, "The Lord will deliver us." Have any of the gods of the nations delivered their land from the hand of the king of Assyria?'

verses.latin: Ubi est deus Emath et Arphad? Ubi est deus Sepharvaim? Numquid liberaverunt Samariam de manu mea?
verses.english: 'Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Did they deliver Samaria from my hand?'

verses.latin: Qui sunt hi inter omnes deos terrarum, qui eruerunt terram suam de manu mea, ut possit eruere Dominus Jerusalem de manu mea?
verses.english: 'Which among all the gods of these lands have ever delivered their land from my hand, that the Lord should be able to deliver Jerusalem from my hand?'

verses.latin: Et tacuerunt, et non responderunt ei verbum: siquidem praeceptum regis fuerat, dicentis: Ne respondeatis ei.
verses.english: But they remained silent and did not answer him a single word, because the king had given a command: 'Do not answer him.'

verses.latin: Et venit Eliacim filius Helciae praepositus domus, et Sobna scriba, et Joah filius Asaph cancellarius ad Hezechiam scissis vestibus, et nuntiaverunt ei verba Rabsacis.
verses.english: Then Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah and the steward of the king's household, along with Shebna the scribe, and Joah, the son of Asaph and the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn in mourning, and they reported to him the words of Rabshakeh.

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum audisset rex Ezechias, scidit vestimenta sua, et obvolutus est sacco, et intravit in domum Domini.
verses.english: When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his clothes and wrapped himself in sackcloth, then he went into the Temple of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et misit Eliacim praepositum domus, et Sobnam scribam, et seniores de sacerdotibus, opertos saccis, ad Isaiam prophetam filium Amos.
verses.english: Hezekiah sent Eliacim, who was the steward of the royal palace, and Sobna the scribe, along with the elders of the priests. All of them were covered in sackcloth, and they went to Isaiah, the prophet and son of Amos.

verses.latin: Et dixerunt ad eum: Haec dicit Ezechias: Dies tribulationis, et increpationis, et blasphemiae, dies hic est: quia venerunt filii usque ad partum, et virtus non est parienti.
verses.english: They said to him: "This is what King Hezekiah says: 'This day is full of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy. It is as if a child has come to the moment of birth, but there is no strength left for the mother to deliver it'—a metaphor for our complete helplessness.'

verses.latin: Si quomodo audiat Dominus Deus tuus verba Rabsacis, quem misit rex Assyriorum dominus suus ad blasphemandum Deum viventem, et ad exprobrandum sermonibus, quos audivit Dominus Deus tuus: leva ergo orationem pro reliquiis, quae repertae sunt.
verses.english: "Perhaps the Lord your God will hear all the words of Rabshakeh, whom the king of Assyria, his master, sent to insult the living God and to scorn Him with the words that the Lord your God has heard. Therefore, please offer a prayer for the remnant of us who are still here and remain in Jerusalem."

verses.latin: Venit ergo servus regis Ezechiae ad Isaiam.
verses.english: So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad eos Isaias: Haec dicetis domino vestro: Haec dicit Dominus: Noli timere a facie sermonum quos audisti, quibus blasphemaverunt pueri regis Assyriorum me.
verses.english: And Isaiah said to them: "You shall say this to your master, King Hezekiah: 'This is what the Lord says: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard—the words with which the young men of the king of Assyria have blasphemed and scorned me.'"

verses.latin: Ecce ego dabo spiritum super eum, et audiet nuntium, et revertetur ad terram suam, et dejiciam eum gladio in terra sua.
verses.english: "Behold, I will put a different spirit upon him, and he will hear a rumor, and he will return to his own land. And I will cause him to be struck down by a sword in his own land."

verses.latin: Reversus est igitur Rabsaces, et invenit regem Assyriorum pugnantem adversus Lobnam: audierat enim quia egressus esset de Lachis.
verses.english: So Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah; for he had heard that the king had departed from Lachish.

verses.latin: Audivit autem de Tharaca rege Aethiopiae, dicentes: Egressus est ut pugnet adversum te. Quod cum audisset, misit nuntios ad Ezechiam, dicens:
verses.english: Then Sennacherib heard concerning Tirhakah, the king of Ethiopia, that he was coming out to fight against him. So when he heard this news, he sent messengers back to Hezekiah, saying:

verses.latin: Haec dicetis Ezechiae regi Juda: Non te decipiat Deus tuus, in quo habes fiduciam, dicens: Non dabitur Jerusalem in manu regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: "You shall say this to Hezekiah, the king of Judah: 'Do not let your God, in whom you place your trust, deceive you by saying: Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.'"

verses.latin: Ecce tu audisti omnia quae fecerunt reges Assyriorum universis terris, et qualiter vastaverunt eas: et tu poteris liberari?
verses.english: "Behold, you yourself have heard all that the kings of Assyria have done to all the lands, and how they utterly destroyed them. Do you truly think you will be able to escape and be delivered?"

verses.latin: Numquid liberaverunt eos dii gentium, quos vastaverunt patres mei, Gozan, et Charan, et Reseph, et filios Eden, qui erant in Thelassar?
verses.english: "Did the false gods of the nations, whom my fathers destroyed, deliver them—nations such as Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the sons of Eden who were in Telassar?"

verses.latin: Ubi est rex Emath, et rex Arphad, et rex urbis Sepharvaim, Ana, et Ava?
verses.english: "Where is the king of Hamath now, and the king of Arpad, and the king of the city of Sepharvaim, of Hena, and of Ivah?"

verses.latin: Et accepit Ezechias libros de manu nuntiorum, et legit eos, et ascendit in domum Domini, et explicavit eos Ezechias coram Domino.
verses.english: And Hezekiah received the letters from the hands of the messengers and read them. Then he went up into the Temple of the Lord and spread the letters out before the Lord.

verses.latin: Et oravit Ezechias ad Dominum, dicens:
verses.english: And Hezekiah prayed to the Lord, saying:

verses.latin: Domine exercituum, Deus Israel, qui sedes super Cherubim, tu es Deus solus omnium regnorum terrae, tu fecisti caelum et terram.
verses.english: "O Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, You who sit enthroned above the Cherubim, You alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You are the one who created the universe and the earth itself."

verses.latin: Inclina, Domine, aurem tuam, et audi: aperi, Domine, oculos tuos, et vide: et audi omnia verba Sennacherib, quae misit ad blasphemandum Deum viventem.
verses.english: "Incline Your ear, O Lord, and hear. Open Your eyes, O Lord, and see. Hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he sent to blaspheme the living God."

verses.latin: Vere enim, Domine, vastaverunt reges Assyriorum terras, et regiones eorum.
verses.english: "It is true, O Lord, that the kings of Assyria have laid waste the lands and their territories."

verses.latin: Et miserunt deos eorum in ignem: non enim erant dii, sed opera manuum hominum, lignum et lapis, et comminuerunt eos.
verses.english: "And they threw the gods of those nations into the fire, because they were not true gods, but merely the work of human hands—objects of wood and stone. And so the Assyrians utterly destroyed them."

verses.latin: Et nunc Domine Deus noster, salva nos de manu ejus, et sciant omnia regna terrae quia tu es Dominus solus.
verses.english: "And now, O Lord our God, save us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You alone are the Lord."

verses.latin: Et misit Isaias filius Amos ad Ezechiam, dicens: Haec dicit Dominus Deus Israel: Pro eo quod orasti me super Sennacherib regem Assyriorum,
verses.english: Then Isaiah, the son of Amos, sent a message to Hezekiah, saying: "This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: 'Because you have prayed to me concerning Sennacherib, the king of Assyria—'"

verses.latin: Ista est verba, quae locutus est Dominus de eo: Sprevit te, et derisit te virgo filia Sion: post te caput movit filia Jerusalem.
verses.english: "These are the words that the Lord has spoken about him: 'The virgin daughter of Zion despises you and mocks you. The daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head at you as you depart.'"

verses.latin: Cui exprobrasti, et quem blasphemasti? et super quem exaltasti vocem, et elevasti in excelsum oculos tuos? Ad sanctum Israel.
verses.english: "Whom have you scorned and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice, and lifted your eyes arrogantly on high? It was against the Holy One of Israel."

verses.latin: In manu servorum tuorum exprobrasti Domino, et dixisti: In multitudine curruum meorum ascendi excelsa montium, in vertice Libani, et succidi sublimia cedrorum ejus, et electas abietes ejus, et ingredi culmen ejus, et saltum Carmeli ejus.
verses.english: "By the hand of your servants, you have insulted the Lord, and you have said: 'With the multitude of my chariots, I have ascended to the highest peaks of the mountains, to the very top of Lebanon. I have cut down its tallest cedars and its choicest fir trees. I will reach its highest summit, even its densest forest of Carmel.'"

verses.latin: Ego fodi, et bibi aquam, et siccavi vestigio pedis mei omnes rivos aggerum.
verses.english: "I myself have dug wells and drunk water. And with the sole of my foot, I have dried up all the rivers meant to protect the besieged cities."

verses.latin: Numquid non audisti? a longe feci illud, ex diebus antiquis formavi illud: et nunc adduxi, et factum est in ruinam collium compugnantium, et civitatum munitarum.
verses.english: "Have you not heard that I—the Lord—ordained this long ago? From ancient days I formed this plan. Now I have brought it to pass, and you have become the instrument for laying waste fortified cities and their defensive mounds."

verses.latin: Et habitatores earum infirmati sunt manu, et conturbati sunt atque confusi, facti sunt sicut foenum agri, et herba pascuae, et tegularum tecti, quae arefacta est antequam maturesceret.
verses.english: "And the inhabitants of those lands were weakened, dismayed, and utterly confounded. They became like the grass of the field, or the plants of the pasture, or the vegetation on the housetops that withers away before it can even mature."

verses.latin: Requiem tuam, et egressum tuum, et introitum tuum, et viam tuam scivi, et insaniam tuam contra me.
verses.english: "I know your resting place, your going out, your coming in, and the path you take, and your furious rage against me."

verses.latin: Cum rabidus fueris in me, et superbia tua ascendit in aures meas, projiciam frenum in naribus tuis, et camum in labiis tuis, et reducam te in viam per quam venisti.
verses.english: "Because you have raged violently against me, and your arrogance has risen to reach my ears, I will put a hook in your nose and a bridle in your mouth, and I will lead you back by the very way you came."

verses.latin: Tibi autem hoc erit signum: comede hoc anno, quae sponte nascuntur, et in anno secundo pomis vescere: in anno autem tertio seminate et metite, et plantate vineas, et comedite fructum earum.
verses.english: "And this will be a sign for you, O Hezekiah: This year, you shall eat what grows of itself. In the second year, you shall eat what grows from the first year's harvest. But in the third year, you shall sow and reap, plant vineyards, and eat their fruit."

verses.latin: Et mittet id, quod evaserit de domo Juda, et quod reliquum fuerit, radices deorsum, et faciet fructum sursum.
verses.english: "And the remnant that has escaped from the house of Judah, that which remains, shall again take deep root below and bear fruit above."

verses.latin: De Jerusalem quippe exibunt reliquiae, et quod salvetur de monte Sion: zelus Domini exercituum faciet hoc.
verses.english: "For out of Jerusalem will come forth a remnant, and from Mount Zion will come those who are saved. The fervent zeal of the Lord of Armies will accomplish this."

verses.latin: Propterea haec dicit Dominus de rege Assyriorum: Non ingredietur civitatem hanc, nec mittet in eam sagittam, nec occupabit eam clypeus, nec fundet circa eam aggerem.
verses.english: "Therefore, this is what the Lord says concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not enter this city, nor shoot an arrow into it, nor approach it with a shield, nor build a siege ramp against it."

verses.latin: In via qua venit, revertetur, et civitatem hanc non ingredietur, dicit Dominus.
verses.english: "By the very road on which he came, he will return. He shall not enter this city, declares the Lord."

verses.latin: Et protegam civitatem istam, ut salvem eam propter me, et propter David servum meum.
verses.english: "And I will protect this city and deliver it, for my own sake and for the sake of David, my faithful servant."

verses.latin: Egressus est autem angelus Domini, et percussit in castris Assyriorum centum octoginta quinque millia. Et surrexerunt mane, et ecce omnes cadavera mortuorum.
verses.english: Then the Angel of the Lord went out and struck down one hundred eighty-five thousand men in the camp of the Assyrians. When people rose early in the morning, behold, all of them were dead bodies.

verses.latin: Et recessit, et abiit Sennacherib rex Assyriorum, et reversus est, et mansit in Ninive.
verses.english: So Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, departed and went away. He returned home and settled in Nineveh.

verses.latin: Cumque adoraret in templo Nesroch dei sui, Adramelech et Sarasar filii ejus percusserunt eum gladio: et ipsi fugerunt in terram Armeniorum: et regnavit Asarhaddon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: While he was worshipping in the temple of Nisroch, his pagan god, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with a sword. Then they fled into the land of Armenia. And Esarhaddon, his son, reigned in his place as king.

verses.latin: In diebus illis ægrotavit Ezechias usque ad mortem. Et introivit ad eum Isaias, filius Amos, propheta, et dixit ei: Hæc dicit Dominus: Dispone domui tuæ, quia morieris tu, et non vives.
verses.english: In those days, King Hezekiah became very sick, so sick that he was going to die. Isaiah, the son of Amos, who was a prophet of God, came to him and said, "This is what the Lord God says: 'Put your affairs in order—prepare your household for your death—for you will surely die and not live.'"

verses.latin: Et convertit Ezechias faciem suam ad parietem, et oravit ad Dominum,
verses.english: When Hezekiah heard this, he turned his face toward the wall and began to pray to the Lord God.

verses.latin: et dixit: Obsecro Domine, memento, quæso, quomodo ambulaverim coram te in veritate, et in corde perfecto, et quæ placita fuerint coram te fecerim. Et flevit Ezechias fletu magno.
verses.english: And Hezekiah prayed, saying, "Oh Lord, I beg you, please remember how I have lived before you—I have always walked honestly and with a complete heart, and I have done what you found pleasing." Then Hezekiah wept with great sorrow.

verses.latin: Et factum est verbum Domini ad Isaiam, dicentem:
verses.english: Then the word of the Lord God came to Isaiah, saying:

verses.latin: Vade, et dic Ezechiæ: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus David patris tui: Audivi orationem tuam, et lacrimam tuam: ecce ego adjiciam super dies tuos quindecim annos:
verses.english: "Go and tell Hezekiah: 'This is what the Lord God, the God of your father David, says: I have heard your prayer and I have seen your tears. Now, behold, I will add fifteen more years to your life.

verses.latin: et de manu regis Assyriorum eruam te, et civitatem istam, et protegam eam.
verses.english: And I will rescue you and this city from the power of the king of Assyria, and I will protect this city.'"

verses.latin: Hoc autem erit signum tibi a Domino, quia faciet Dominus verbum hoc, quod locutus est:
verses.english: And this will be your sign from the Lord God, that the Lord God will indeed do this thing that He has spoken.

verses.latin: Ecce ego reverti faciam umbram linearum per quas descenderat in horologio Achaz, retrorsum decem lineis. Et reversus est sol decem lineis per gradus quos descenderat.
verses.english: "Behold, I will cause the shadow on the steps of Ahaz's sundial—the steps by which it had already descended—to go back ten steps." And the sun's shadow on the sundial did indeed go back ten steps from where it had descended, demonstrating God's power over time.

verses.latin: Scriptura Ezechiæ regis Juda, cum ægrotasset et recreatus esset de infirmitate sua.
verses.english: This is a written prayer and record by King Hezekiah of Judah, composed after he had been sick and then had recovered from his illness.

verses.latin: Ego dixi: In dimidio dierum meorum vadam ad portas inferi: quæsivi residuum annorum meorum.
verses.english: I had said to myself, "In the middle of my life, I will go down to the gates of the grave—the realm of the dead. I thought I would be deprived of the rest of my years."

verses.latin: Dixi: Non videbo Dominum Deum in terra viventium. Non aspiciam hominem ultra, et habitatorem quievam.
verses.english: I said, "I will no longer see the Lord God in the land of the living. I will not look upon another human being, nor dwell among those who live in the world anymore."

verses.latin: Generatio mea ablata est, et convoluta est a me, quasi tabernaculum pastorum: præcisa est velut a texente vita mea: dum adhuc ordirer, succidit me: de mane usque ad vesperam finies me.
verses.english: My generation has been taken away, and my life has been folded up from me like a shepherd's tent. My life has been cut off like a weaver's thread from the loom; while I was still weaving it, He cut me off. From the morning until the evening, you will bring my life to an end.

verses.latin: Sperabam usque ad mane, quasi leo sic contrivit omnia ossa mea: de mane usque ad vesperam finies me.
verses.english: I waited patiently until morning, but like a lion, God crushed all my bones. From the morning until the evening, you will bring my life to an end.

verses.latin: Sicut pullus hirundinis sic clamabo, meditabor ut columba: attenuati sunt oculi mei, suspicientes in excelsum. Domine, vim patior, responde pro me.
verses.english: I chirped like a young swallow, and I mourned like a dove. My eyes grew dim from looking upward, constantly begging for help. Lord, I am suffering great violence and oppression—please answer for me.

verses.latin: Quid dicam, aut quid respondebit mihi, cum ipse fecerit? Recogitabo omnes annos meos in amaritudine animæ meæ.
verses.english: What can I say? What will He answer me when He Himself has done this—permitted this to happen? I will remember all my past years in the bitterness of my soul.

verses.latin: Domine, si sic vivitur, et perfecta est in talibus vita spiritus mei, curasti me, et vivificasti me.
verses.english: O Lord, if this is how life is lived by men, and if my spirit's life finds its perfection and purpose in such experiences, then you have healed me and given me life again.

verses.latin: Ecce in pace amaritudo mea amarissima: tu autem eruisti animam meam ut non periret, projecisti post tergum tuum omnia peccata mea.
verses.english: Behold, in my peace—in my supposed rest—my bitterness was most bitter. But you, O Lord, have rescued my soul so that it would not perish; you have cast all my sins behind your back, completely removing them from your sight.

verses.latin: Quia non infernus confitebitur tibi, neque mors laudabit te: non sperabunt qui descendunt in lacum, veritatem tuam.
verses.english: For the realm of the dead will not give thanks to you, nor will death praise you. Those who descend into the pit—into the grave—will not hope for your truth.

verses.latin: Vivens, vivens ipse confitebitur tibi, sicut et ego hodie: pater filiis notam faciet veritatem tuam.
verses.english: The living, yes, the living, will give thanks to you, just as I do today. A father will make your truth known to his children.

verses.latin: Domine, salvum me fac, et psalmos nostros cantabimus cunctis diebus vitæ nostræ in domo Domini.
verses.english: O Lord, save me! And we will sing our psalms all the days of our lives in the house of the Lord God.

verses.latin: Et dixit Isaias: Afferte massam de ficis, et ponite super vulnus, et curabitur.
verses.english: And Isaiah said, "Bring a cake of figs, and apply it to the boil, and he will recover."

verses.latin: Et dixit Ezechias: Quod erit signum, quia ascendam in domum Domini?
verses.english: Then Hezekiah asked, "What will be the sign that I will go up to the house of the Lord God again?"

verses.latin: In tempore illo misit Merodach Baladan, filius Baladan, rex Babylonis, litteras et munera ad Ezechiam: audierat enim quod ægrotasset, et convaluisset.
verses.english: In that time, Merodach-Baladan, son of Baladan, who was the king of Babylon, sent letters and gifts to King Hezekiah. This was because he had heard that Hezekiah had become ill and then recovered.

verses.latin: Lætatus est autem super eis Ezechias, et ostendit eis domum thesauro suo, argentum et aurum, et aromata, et unguenta optima, et universam supellectilem domus suæ, et cuncta quæ inventa sunt in thesauris suis. Non fuit verbum quod non ostenderet eis Ezechias in domo sua, et in omni potestate sua.
verses.english: King Hezekiah was greatly pleased by their visit and gifts, and he showed them everything in his royal treasury. He revealed his silver, his gold, all his spices, the finest oils, and all the furnishings within his palace. Hezekiah held nothing back from them from his treasures or from all that was under his authority.

verses.latin: Et veniit Isaias propheta ad regem Ezechiam, et dixit ad eum: Quid dixerunt viri isti, et unde venerunt ad te? Et dixit Ezechias: De terra longinqua venerunt ad me, de Babylone.
verses.english: After this, the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and asked him: 'What did those men say to you? And where did they come from to reach you?' Hezekiah responded: 'They came to me from a very distant land, from Babylon.'

verses.latin: Et dixit: Quid viderunt in domo tua? Et dixit Ezechias: Omnia quæ in domo mea sunt viderunt: non fuit res quam non ostenderim eis in thesauris meis.
verses.english: Isaiah then asked: 'What did they see in your royal palace?' Hezekiah replied: 'They saw everything that is in my house; there was nothing among my treasures that I did not show them.'

verses.latin: Et dixit Isaias ad Ezechiam: Audi verbum Domini exercituum.
verses.english: Then Isaiah spoke to Hezekiah: 'Listen closely to the message from the Lord of armies.'

verses.latin: Ecce dies venient, et auferentur omnia quæ in domo tua sunt, et quæ condiderunt patres tui usque ad diem hanc in Babylonem: non relinquetur quicquam, dicit Dominus.
verses.english: Indeed, the days are coming when everything in your royal palace, and all the riches your ancestors have accumulated until this very day, will be taken away to Babylon. Nothing will be left behind, declares the Lord God.

verses.latin: Et de filiis tuis, qui exibunt de te, quos genueris, tollent, et erunt eunuchi in palatio regis Babylonis.
verses.english: And some of your own sons, those who will be born to you and descend from you, will be taken away. They will be made eunuchs and forced to serve in the palace of the king of Babylon.

verses.latin: Et dixit Ezechias ad Isaiam: Bonum est verbum Domini quod locutus es. Et dixit: Tantùm fiat pax et veritas in diebus meis.
verses.english: Hezekiah responded to Isaiah: 'The message from the Lord God that you have spoken is good.' He then added: 'At least there will be peace and security during my lifetime.'

verses.latin: Consolamini, consolamini, popule meus, dicit Deus vester.
verses.english: “Comfort, comfort my people,” says your God, calling them to be consoled.

verses.latin: Loquimini ad cor Jerusalem, et vocate ad eam: quoniam completa est malitia ejus, dimissa est iniquitas illius: suscepit de manu Domini duplicia pro omnibus peccatis suis.
verses.english: Speak directly and tenderly to Jerusalem; tell her that her time of suffering has been completed. Her iniquity has been forgiven, for she has received from the Lord’s hand a double portion of recompense for all her sins.

verses.latin: Vox clamantis in deserto: Parate viam Domini, rectas facite in solitudine semitas Dei nostri.
verses.english: There is a voice of one calling out in the wilderness, saying: “Prepare the road for the Lord! Make the pathways of our God straight in the barren lands!”

verses.latin: Omnis vallis exaltabitur, et omnis mons et collis humiliabitur: et erunt prava in directa, et aspera in vias planas.
verses.english: Every low valley will be elevated, and every mountain and hill will be made low. The twisted roads will become straight, and the rough, uneven ground will become smooth pathways.

verses.latin: Et revelabitur gloria Domini: et videbit omnis caro pariter, quod os Domini locutum est.
verses.english: And then the radiant glory of the Lord will be revealed, and all humanity will see it together, for the mouth of the Lord God has spoken this truth.

verses.latin: Vox dicentis: Clama. Et dixi: Quid clamabo? Omnis caro foenum, et omnis gloria ejus quasi flos agri.
verses.english: A voice then commanded: “Cry out!” And I answered: “What message should I proclaim?” The voice responded: “All human beings are as fleeting as grass, and all their earthly splendor is like a fragile wildflower.”

verses.latin: Exsiccatum est foenum, et cecidit flos: quia spiritus Domini sufflavit in eo. Vere foenum est populus.
verses.english: The grass dries up, and the flower fades away, because the breath of the Lord (like a strong wind) blows over it. Indeed, human beings are as transient as grass.

verses.latin: Siccatum est foenum, et cecidit flos: verbum autem Domini nostri manet in aeternum.
verses.english: The grass dries up, and the flower fades away, but the word and eternal decree of our God remains for all eternity.

verses.latin: Super montem excelsum ascende tu qui evangelizas Sion: exalta in fortitudine vocem tuam qui evangelizas Jerusalem. Exalta, noli timere: dic civitatibus Juda: Ecce Deus vester.
verses.english: Go up onto a high mountain, you who bring the good news of salvation to Sion! Raise your voice with all your strength, you who proclaim the good news to Jerusalem! Raise it up without fear! Say to the cities of Judah: “Behold, here is your God!”

verses.latin: Ecce Dominus Deus in fortitudine veniet, et brachium ejus dominabitur: ecce merces ejus cum eo, et opus illius coram illo.
verses.english: Behold, the Lord God will come with overwhelming power, and His mighty arm will have dominion. Behold, His eternal reward is with Him, and His works of salvation are before His face.

verses.latin: Sicut pastor gregem suum pascet: in brachio suo congregabit agnos, et in sinu suo levabit: foetas ipse portabit.
verses.english: Like a shepherd, He will feed His flock. He will gather the young lambs with His arm and carry them close to His chest, and He Himself will gently lead the ewes that are pregnant or nursing.

verses.latin: Quis mensus est pugillo aquas, et caelos palma ponderavit? quis appendit tribus digitis molem terrae, et libravit in pondere montes, et colles in statera?
verses.english: Who has ever measured the waters of the deep in the hollow of His hand, or weighed the entire universe with His palm? Who has measured the mass of the earth with just three fingers, or balanced the mountains on scales and the hills in a balance?

verses.latin: Quis adjuvit Spiritum Domini, aut quis consiliarius ejus fuit, et ostendit illi?
verses.english: Who has ever guided the Spirit of the Lord, or who has served as His advisor and taught Him how to act?

verses.latin: A quo accepit consilium, et instruxit eum, et docuit eum semitam justitiae, et erudivit eum scientiam, et viam prudentiae ostendit illi?
verses.english: From whom did He receive advice, and who instructed Him, teaching Him the path of righteousness? Who imparted knowledge to Him, and showed Him the way of true understanding?

verses.latin: Ecce gentes quasi stilla situlae, et quasi momentum staterae reputatae sunt: ecce insulae quasi pulvis exiguus.
verses.english: Behold, all the nations of the world are like a single drop falling from a bucket, and they are regarded as nothing more than the fine dust that barely registers on a balance scale. Behold, even the great islands are like tiny specks of dust.

verses.latin: Et Libanus non sufficiet ad succendendum, et animalia ejus non sufficient ad holocaustum.
verses.english: Even the vast forests of Lebanon would not provide enough wood for a fire offering, and its multitude of animals would not be sufficient for a single burnt sacrifice worthy of God.

verses.latin: Omnes gentes quasi non sint, sic sunt coram eo, et quasi nihilum, et inane reputatae sunt.
verses.english: All the nations, in His sight, are as if they do not exist. They are accounted as nothing, utterly empty and void of substance.

verses.latin: Cui ergo assimilastis Deum? aut quam imaginem ponetis ei?
verses.english: To whom, then, will you compare God? Or what created image will you set up as His likeness?

verses.latin: Numquid sculptile? inflat artifex, et aurifex in auro laminas nectit, et argentarius laminas argenteas.
verses.english: Can you liken Him to a carved idol? A craftsman casts a statue, and a goldsmith then covers it with plates of gold, while a silversmith fashions silver plates for it.

verses.latin: Elegit pauper lignum, et in ligno quod putrescere non possit: quaerit artificem scientem, ut paret simulacrum, quod non moveatur.
verses.english: One who is too poor to afford metal chooses a piece of wood that will not rot, then seeks a skilled craftsman to prepare an idol that will stand firm and not topple over.

verses.latin: Numquid non scitis? numquid non audistis? numquid non annuntiatum est vobis ab initio? numquid non intellexistis fundamenta terrae?
verses.english: Do you not know these truths? Have you not heard them proclaimed? Has it not been announced to you from the very beginning of time? Have you not understood the fundamental truth of God’s creation of the entire earth?

verses.latin: Qui sedet super gyrum terrae, et habitatores ejus sunt quasi locustae: qui extendit quasi nihilum caelos, et expandit eos sicut tabernaculum ad inhabitandum.
verses.english: It is He who is enthroned above the spherical earth, and its inhabitants appear before Him like tiny locusts. He effortlessly stretches out the universe as if it were a fine curtain, and spreads it out like a vast tent for habitation.

verses.latin: Qui reducit judices quasi in nihilum, rectores terrae velut inane facit.
verses.english: He brings the powerful judges and rulers of the world to utter nothingness. He renders the governors of the earth as empty and without substance.

verses.latin: Et quidem non plantatus, nec satus, nec radicatus in terra stirps eorum: repente flatum in eos dedit, et arescunt, et turbo quasi stipulam auferet eos.
verses.english: Indeed, they are neither planted like a tree, nor sown like a seed, nor is their lineage deeply rooted in the earth. Suddenly, He breathes a powerful wind upon them, and they instantly wither away. A whirlwind then carries them off like light stubble.

verses.latin: Et cui assimilastis me, et adaequastis, dicit Sanctus?
verses.english: “To whom then can you possibly compare Me, or whom will you consider My equal?” says the Holy One of God.

verses.latin: Levate in excelsum oculos vestros, et videte quis creavit haec: qui educit in numero stellas ejus: et omnes nomine vocat. Propter multitudinem fortitudinis et roboris, et potentiae ejus, neque unum reliquum est.
verses.english: Lift up your eyes to the cosmic expanse above, and see who created all these things: He who brings out their starry host by number, and calls each one by its unique name. Because of the immensity of His strength, His might, and His power, not one star is missing.

verses.latin: Quare dicis, Jacob, et loqueris, Israel: Abscondita est via mea a Domino, et judicium meum a Deo meo transiit?
verses.english: Why do you complain, O Jacob, and why do you say, O Israel: “My path and my struggles are hidden from the Lord, and my rightful cause is ignored by my God?”

verses.latin: Numquid nescis, aut non audisti? Deus sempiternus Dominus, qui creavit fines terrae: non deficiet, neque laborabit, nec est investigatio sapientiae ejus.
verses.english: Do you not know this, or have you not heard? The Lord is the eternal God, the Creator of the entire earth. He does not grow faint, nor does He become weary. His wisdom and understanding are utterly beyond our ability to comprehend.

verses.latin: Qui dat lasso virtutem, et his qui non sunt, fortitudinem multiplicat.
verses.english: He grants strength and vigor to the weary, and He multiplies the might of those who have no power of their own.

verses.latin: Deficient pueri, et laborabunt: et juvenes in infirmitate cadent.
verses.english: Even the strongest young men will grow weary and faint, and the most robust youths will utterly stumble and fall.

verses.latin: Qui autem sperant in Domino, mutabunt fortitudinem, assument pennas sicut aquilae, current et non laborabunt, ambulabunt et non deficient.
verses.english: But those who place their hope and trust in the Lord will find their strength renewed. They will soar on high with wings like eagles, they will run a race and not grow weary, they will walk a long journey and not faint.

verses.latin: Tacete ad me, insulae, et gentes mutent fortitudinem: accedant, et tunc loquantur: propinquemus simul ad judicium.
verses.english: Be silent before Me, you distant lands and coastal regions. Let the nations renew their strength and their resolve. Let them come forward and then speak. Let us all approach together to make our case before judgment.

verses.latin: Quis excitavit ab Oriente justum, vocavit eum ut sequeretur se, dedit in conspectu ejus gentes, et reges humiliabit? dabit quasi pulverem gladio ejus, sicut stipulam vento raptam arcui ejus.
verses.english: Who has raised up from the East a righteous man? Who called him to follow God's will and purpose? Who gave nations into his view, enabling him to humble kings? He will make their armies like dust to his sword, and their forces like stubble scattered by the wind to his bow.

verses.latin: Persequetur eos, transibit in pace, semita qua non ambulavit pes ejus.
verses.english: He will pursue them and pass onward in peace, on a path where his own foot has never walked before—a path made easy by God.

verses.latin: Quis haec operatus est, et fecit, vocans generationes ab exordio? Ego Dominus, primus et novissimus ego sum.
verses.english: Who has worked and accomplished these things? Who has called forth all the generations of humanity from the very beginning of time? I am the Lord, the First and the Last, I am He.

verses.latin: Viderunt insulae, et timuerunt: extrema terrae obstupuerunt, appropinquaverunt et accesserunt.
verses.english: The distant lands saw what happened and became afraid. The farthest regions of the earth were astonished; they drew near and came together.

verses.latin: Unusquisque proximo suo auxiliatus est, et fratri suo dixit: Confortare.
verses.english: Everyone helped his neighbor, and each one said to his brother: 'Take courage! Be strong!'

verses.latin: Confortavit faber aerarius, percutiens malleo, eum qui cudebat tunc temporis, dicens: Bonus est hic lictor. Et firmavit eum clavis, ut non moveretur.
verses.english: The metal craftsman encouraged the goldsmith, who was hammering the idol with his mallet, saying: 'This joining is good!' And he fastened it with nails so that it would not fall or move.

verses.latin: Et tu Israel, servus meus, Jacob quem elegi, semen Abraham amici mei:
verses.english: But you, Israel, are My servant, Jacob whom I have chosen, the offspring of Abraham, My beloved friend.

verses.latin: in quo apprehendi te ab extremis terrae, et de longinquis ejus vocavi te, et dixi tibi: Servus meus es tu, elegi te, et non abjeci te.
verses.english: I have taken you from the very ends of the earth and called you from its farthest corners. I have said to you: 'You are My chosen servant; I have called you, and I have never cast you away.'

verses.latin: Ne timeas, quia ego tecum sum: ne declines, quia ego Deus tuus: confortavi te, et auxiliatus sum tibi, et suscepi te dextera justi mei.
verses.english: Do not fear, for I am with you. Do not be dismayed or look around for help, for I am your God. I have strengthened you and helped you. I have sustained you with the triumphant right hand of My justice.

verses.latin: Ecce confundentur, et erubescent omnes qui pugnant adversum te: erunt quasi non sint, et peribunt viri qui contendunt tecum.
verses.english: Behold, all those who fight against you will be utterly put to shame and disgraced. They will be reduced to nothing and will perish, the men who strive against you.

verses.latin: Quaeres eos, et non invenies viros rebelles tuos: erunt quasi non sint, et veluti nihilum, bellantes adversum te.
verses.english: You will search for them, but you will not find those who rebelled against you. They will become as if they never existed, and those who waged war against you will be reduced to nothing.

verses.latin: Quia ego Dominus Deus tuus apprehendens manum tuam, dicensque tibi: Ne timeas, ego adjuvi te.
verses.english: For I am the Lord your God, holding your right hand firmly, and saying to you: 'Do not fear; I Myself have helped you.'

verses.latin: Noli timere, vermis Jacob, et qui mortui estis ex Israel: ego auxiliatus sum tibi, dicit Dominus, et redemptor tuus Sanctus Israel.
verses.english: Do not be afraid, you humbled people of Jacob, you seemingly insignificant ones from Israel. I Myself have helped you, says the Lord. And your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel.

verses.latin: Ego feci te quasi plaustrum triturans novum, habens rostra serrata: triturabis montes, et comminues, et colles sicut pulverem pones.
verses.english: Behold, I will make you like a new threshing sledge, equipped with sharp, serrated teeth. You will thresh mountains and crush them, reducing the hills to mere dust.

verses.latin: Ventilabis eos, et ventus tollet, et turbo disperget eos: et tu exsultabis in Domino, in Sancto Israel laetaberis.
verses.english: You will winnow them, and the wind will carry them away, and a strong gale will scatter them. And you yourself will rejoice triumphantly in the Lord, you will find your joy in the Holy One of Israel.

verses.latin: Egeni et pauperes quaerunt aquas, et non sunt: lingua eorum siti aruit. Ego Dominus exaudiam eos, Deus Israel non derelinquam eos.
verses.english: The poor and the needy are searching for water, but there is none; their tongues are parched with thirst. I, the Lord, will certainly hear their cries. I, the God of Israel, will not abandon them.

verses.latin: Aperiam in altis flumina, et in medio camporum fontes: desertum in stagna aquarum, et terram sitientem in scaturigines aquarum.
verses.english: I will open rivers on the barren heights and springs in the middle of the valleys. I will transform the desert into refreshing pools of water, and the thirsty ground into gushing springs.

verses.latin: Dabo in solitudine cedrum, et spinam, et myrtum, et lignum olivae: ponam in deserto abietem, ulmum, et buxum simul:
verses.english: I will plant in the barren wilderness the cedar, the acacia (also called the shittah tree), the myrtle, and the olive tree. I will set in the desert the fir, the elm, and the boxwood all together.

verses.latin: ut videant, et sciant, et cogitent, et intelligant pariter, quia manus Domini fecit hoc, et Sanctus Israel creavit illud.
verses.english: So that all people may see and fully know, consider deeply, and understand together that the hand of the Lord God has accomplished this, and the Holy One of Israel Himself has created these things.

verses.latin: Proferte causam vestram, dicit Dominus: afferte si quid forte vultis, ait Rex Jacob.
verses.english: Present your case for your gods, says the Lord. Bring forth all your strongest arguments, says the King of Jacob.

verses.latin: Accedant, et nuntient nobis quaecumque ventura sunt: priora quae fuerunt, nuntiate, et ponemus cor nostrum, et sciemus novissima eorum: et quae ventura sunt, annuntiate nobis.
